content: Tangler; quote: #1) It's "oil rig's" not "refineries", refineries are were you ship oil to to create gasoline and diesel and other oil products. Actually, no, it's refineries, they need more of them. quote: #3) The oil companys are already at the limit of their refineries and aren't intrested in building more as at this time they are running the price of oil back up to the point where they are making extreme profits with out getting to many people upset by their horz. monopoly. Which is WHY they need more refineries.. And if you pay attention you'd know it's NOT the oil companies that are running the price of oil back up, it's OPEC is running the price of oil up.. "http://news.yahoo.com/s/time/20090529/wl_time/08599190144600" quote: The 12 member countries of the OPEC cartel voted in Vienna on Thursday to maintain output at current levels rather than increase supplies in order to bring some relief to consumers, particularly in the gas-guzzling West. The OPEC oil ministers, whose countries account for about 40% of the world's entire crude-oil supply, also renewed their commitment to stick to their agreed quotas, rather than ship extra oil, as they began doing last April when several members ignored their agreed output limits. OPEC leaders, many of whose economies are heavily dependent on oil exports, have struggled to stabilize prices at a level that suits their own economic needs amid falling demand and rising supplies. Prices had rocketed to a record level of $147 a barrel last July before plummeting to $30 just five months later and beginning a new climb.

content: quote: Originally posted by Yooper_tj: I don't think you could call it 'smart' to ignore mile after square mile of desert in the southwest, just waiting for American Built and Erected (ha--erected!) solar panels and windmills...I get 40 percent of my household electricity from a hydroelectric power plant built more than 100 years ago. It's not any cheaper, but then again it just keeps going and going like the Energizer Bunny ---no matter how much or how little oil OPEC decides to let us buy. This isn't an all or nothing proposition, folks. Gunny's right--we'll always need oil, and best our own, but there's a finite supply, and we'd be well-served to run our air conditioners and blogographic telecommunications devices with electricity from the other sources God (and a few engineers here on earth) so generously provided. How long will the environmentalists hold up the process due to impact on the fragile desert ecosystem? Heck people are already "concerned" over wind turbones and the impact on birds.

content: Well, ." 95% of all green house gases are caused by water evaporation, of the remaining 5% only 1% is CO2. Of that 1% only 3% is produced by using fossil fuels. 2. Looking back 50 years, global warming periods preceded CO2 increases by 9 months according to Dr. Allen M.R. McRae. CO2 emissions due to human activity rose gradually from the onset of the Industrial Revolution, reaching 1 billion tonnes per year (expressed as carbon) by 1945, and then accelerated to 9 billion tonnes per year by 2007. Since 1945 when CO2 emissions accelerated, Earth experienced 22 years of warming, and 40 years of either cooling or absence of warming. 3. CO2 has the ability to raise temperatures - but not by much. The reason is that CO2 is logarithmic - meaning each unit of CO2 emitted has less ability to heat than the preceding unit. In fact, the first 20ppm of CO2 has more heating capacity than the next 400ppm. 4. Scientists from the IPCC, Canada, Russia, the United States and other countries now believe because of solar inactivity we are entering a global cooling period. This will challenge nations around the globe to keep their populations warm which takes even more energy (note: China is currently suffering through its worst winter in 100 years). I believe, however, that we must move away from fossil fuels in the short term for nation security reasons (stop the dependence on foreign oil). I believe in the long term we will move from the more efficient and cost effective fossil fuels to, for the first time in our history, less efficient and more costly renewable energy sources (nuclear, wind, solar) because fossil fuels are a finite resource. We will consume all of our oil, coal and natural gas. The question is not if, but when." and: "1. The Horse Hollow Wind Energy Center in Texas remains the largest wind farm in the world with a total capacity of 735 megawatts (MW) spread across approximately 47,000 acres in Taylor and Nolan counties near Abilene in west central Texas. The wind plant consists of 291 1.5-MW wind turbines from General Electric and 130 2.3-MW wind turbines from Siemens. 2. I used the bigger 2.3 MW wind turbines (which are 370+ feet tall) from Siemens to meet our current power deficit of 4,150 MW. That means we would need 1,805 wind turbines. We know from the Horse Hollow Wind Energy Center that they needed 47,000 acres for their 421 wind turbines. So we in Florida would need 4.29 times the acres of the Texas wind farm or approximately 201,508 acres. Bottom line we would need approximately 201,508 acres of land to simply replace the capacity of the cancelled plants. Of course, Florida can put the wind farms in the Gulf of Mexico and bypass the need to use massive amounts of land. Either way the solution of using wind power is difficult at best to meet the current deficit, let alone any future energy." from: ""http://www.zimbio.com/Wind+power/articles/10/Florida+s+Energy+Deficit And pleaase recall, things CAN become becalmed, then we get the energy from....? Anyway, with nat. gas there is plenty of energy available. Read here: ""http://www.eia.doe.gov/pub/oil_gas/natural_gas/data_publications/crude_oil_natural_gas_reserves/current/pdf/arr.pdf Staggering, isn't it? And then there are the clathtrates of Natural Gas , trillions more cubic feet..... And COMPACT NUCLEAR: ""http://earth2tech.com/2008/08/01/hyperions-nuclear-in-a-box-ready-by-2013/ ""http://web.mit.edu/pebble-bed/papers1_files/PBReactors.pdf A backyard or two of hundreds of thousands , perhaps millions, of acres devoted to wind turbines.....is there even any question?
reply: Well, ." 95% of all green house gases are caused by water evaporation, of the remaining 5% only 1% is CO2. Of that 1% only 3% is produced by using fossil fuels. 2. Looking back 50 years, global warming periods preceded CO2 increases by 9 months according to Dr. Allen M.R. McRae. CO2 emissions due to human activity rose gradually from the onset of the Industrial Revolution, reaching 1 billion tonnes per year (expressed as carbon) by 1945, and then accelerated to 9 billion tonnes per year by 2007. Since 1945 when CO2 emissions accelerated, Earth experienced 22 years of warming, and 40 years of either cooling or absence of warming. 3. CO2 has the ability to raise temperatures - but not by much. The reason is that CO2 is logarithmic - meaning each unit of CO2 emitted has less ability to heat than the preceding unit. In fact, the first 20ppm of CO2 has more heating capacity than the next 400ppm. 4. Scientists from the IPCC, Canada, Russia, the United States and other countries now believe because of solar inactivity we are entering a global cooling period. This will challenge nations around the globe to keep their populations warm which takes even more energy (note: China is currently suffering through its worst winter in 100 years). I believe, however, that we must move away from fossil fuels in the short term for nation security reasons (stop the dependence on foreign oil). I believe in the long term we will move from the more efficient and cost effective fossil fuels to, for the first time in our history, less efficient and more costly renewable energy sources (nuclear, wind, solar) because fossil fuels are a finite resource. We will consume all of our oil, coal and natural gas. The question is not if, but when." and: "1. The wind plant consists of 291 1.5-MW wind turbines from General Electric and 130 2.3-MW wind turbines from Siemens. 2. I used the bigger 2.3 MW wind turbines (which are 370+ feet tall) from Siemens to meet our current power deficit of 4,150 MW. That means we would need 1,805 wind turbines. We know from the Horse Hollow Wind Energy Center that they needed 47,000 acres for their 421 wind turbines. So we in Florida would need 4.29 times the acres of the Texas wind farm or approximately 201,508 acres. Bottom line we would need approximately 201,508 acres of land to simply replace the capacity of the cancelled plants. Of course, Florida can put the wind farms in the Gulf of Mexico and bypass the need to use massive amounts of land. Either way the solution of using wind power is difficult at best to meet the current deficit, let alone any future energy." from: ""http://www.zimbio.com/Wind+power/articles/10/Florida+s+Energy+Deficit And pleaase recall, things CAN become becalmed, then we get the energy from....? Anyway, with nat. gas there is plenty of energy available. Read here: ""http://www.eia.doe.gov/pub/oil_gas/natural_gas/data_publications/crude_oil_natural_gas_reserves/current/pdf/arr.pdf Staggering, isn't it? And then there are the clathtrates of Natural Gas , trillions more cubic feet..... And COMPACT NUCLEAR: ""http://earth2tech.com/2008/08/01/hyperions-nuclear-in-a-box-ready-by-2013/ ""http://web.mit.edu/pebble-bed/papers1_files/PBReactors.pdf A backyard or two of hundreds of thousands , perhaps millions, of acres devoted to wind turbines.....is there even any question?
title: Drill baby drill...It wasn't a slogan

content: quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: quote: Originally posted by Irwin_R_Schyster: Gunny: Isn't it funny and sad watching these libtards?? They want "green" energy but refuse to endanger any wildlife in the process...LOL Thats why your plan is a damn joke libtards, it is a damn pipe-dream commercially. Yep, all those little hybrids fartin around town. When the batteries are spent where do they go? Damn good point.. That reminds me, Where do the Apple laptops go after they are used up libs?? Or any laptop? Where does all of our technology end up when it becomes trash... Well now, let's try to inprove your IQ of Irwin_R_Schyster and GunnyRet03: Recycling in the U.S. and Canada. In 2001, the Apple Recycles program began a takeback service for our customers in the US and Canada. This program has recycled over 90% (by weight) of all the electronic equipment collected. Apple recycling program Apple’s commitment to being a responsible environmental citizen includes working to ensure that electronic equipment is properly disposed of at the end of its useful life. Apple’s free computer and iPod recycling programs in the US make it easy for consumers to help protect the environment. Apple customers in the US have several options for recycling their used iPods, systems, and displays. Apple has expanded its successful recycling program, offering free computer takeback and recycling with the purchase of a new Mac. US customers who buy a new Mac through the Apple Store or Apple’s retail stores will receive free shipping and environmentally friendly disposal of their old computer. So as you see we eco-lib.s are out there cleaning up your mess, both political and ecological. Have a nice day...

content: quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: Yep, all those little hybrids fartin around town. When the batteries are spent where do they go? Today's hybrids use NiMH batteries, not nickel cadmium. Nickel metal hydride batteries can be fully recycled.
quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: Yep, all those little hybrids fartin around town. When the batteries are spent where do they go?
reply: Today's hybrids use NiMH batteries, not nickel cadmium. Nickel metal hydride batteries can be fully recycled.
title: Drill baby drill...It wasn't a slogan
